choices.text: Nelson syndrome
Sheehan syndrome
Conn's syndrome

questions.text: A woman comes with complaints of hyperpigmentation of her palms after an adrenalectomy. She also has new onset vision deficits. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nelson syndrome

 

Explanation:  

 

Nelson syndrome occurs in patients who have undergone bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing's disease due to an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma. After the adrenalectomy, the absence of cortisol feedback leads to increased secretion of ACTH by the pituitary adenoma. This results in:

 

  • Hyperpigmentation: Due to elevated levels of ACTH and its precursor, which stimulates melanocytes.
  • Vision deficits: Caused by the growth of the pituitary adenoma, which can compress the optic chiasma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sheehan syndrome: Caused by postpartum necrosis of the pituitary gland, leading to hypopituitarism. It presents with failure to lactate, amenorrhea, and hypothyroidism, but not with hyperpigmentation or vision deficits post-adrenalectomy.

 

Option C. Conn's syndrome: Primary hyperaldosteronism, characterized by hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. It does not cause hyperpigmentation or vision deficits.

 

Option D. Addison's disease:  Primary adrenal insufficiency presenting with hyperpigmentation due to high ACTH, but it is not typically associated with vision deficits or occurring after adrenalectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nelson syndrome is characterized by hyperpigmentation and vision deficits following bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing's disease, due to the growth of an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to OPD with proptosis of left eye. On investigation, it was found to be a Desmin positive tumour. What can be the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma

 

Given clinical scenario and tumor showing Desmin positive, points to a diagnosis of Embryonal Rhabdomyosarcoma.

 

Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma presents as a soft gray infiltrative mass. The tumor cells mimic skeletal muscle at various stages of differentiation and consist of sheets of both primitive round and spindled cells. Rhabdomyoblasts with straplike cytoplasm and visible cross-striations may be present.

 

Sarcoma botryoides is a variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma that develops in the walls of hollow viscera such as the urinary bladder and vagina.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ewing's sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma is typically positive for CD99 and is more commonly found in bone or soft tissue, not usually associated with Desmin positivity.

 

Option C. Leukemia: Leukemia cells are positive for CD45 (leukocyte common antigen) and are not associated with Desmin positivity or presenting as a soft tissue mass with proptosis.

 

Option D. Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor of the retina, typically presenting with leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) and is associated with RB1 gene mutations. It is not associated with Desmin positivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, a common pediatric soft tissue sarcoma, is typically Desmin-positive and can present with proptosis, particularly when it arises in the orbit.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 2435-2437

questions.text: All blood products are separated by Centrifugation except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serum albumin

 

Most blood components are separated using centrifugation, which involves different speeds:

 

  1. Low-speed centrifugation:
    • Separates Packed RBCs from platelet-rich plasma (PRP).
  2. High-speed centrifugation:
    • Separates platelets from plasma.
    • Plasma is further processed into Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP).
  3. Cryoprecipitate Preparation:
    • FFP is thawed at 1-6°C, allowing cryoprecipitate to form, which contains Factor VIII, fibrinogen, vWF, and Factor XIII.

 

Thus, platelets, RBCs and cryoprecipitate are all separated using centrifugation.

 

Serum albumin, however, is obtained through a process called fractionation, not centrifugation. This involves:

 

  • Cold ethanol precipitation (Cohn’s method)
  • Ultrafiltration and chromatography techniques

 

Educational Objective:

 

Centrifugation is used to separate RBCs, platelets, and plasma-derived components like cryoprecipitate. Serum albumin, however, is obtained through fractionation, making it the correct answer.

choices.text: Colposcopy with LEEP

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has cervical intraepithelial neoplasia III. What would be the management? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Colposcopy with LEEP

 

Explanation:

 

Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia III (CIN 3) is a severe form of cervical dysplasia that is diagnosed by cervical biopsy. The standard treatment for CIN 2 or CIN 3 is an excisional procedure, which aims to remove the affected tissue to prevent progression to invasive cancer.

 

  • LEEP (Loop Electrosurgical Excision Procedure):
    • LEEP is the excisional procedure of choice for treating CIN 3.
    • It involves using a thin wire loop that is heated by electric current to excise the transformation zone of the cervix where abnormal cells are located.
    • LEEP is also known as LLETZ (Large Loop Excision of the Transformation Zone).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hysterectomy: This is a more radical procedure that involves the removal of the uterus. It is generally not the first-line treatment for CIN 3 unless there are other indications, such as concurrent invasive cancer or other gynecological conditions.

 

Option B. Trachelectomy: This procedure involves removing the cervix while preserving the uterus. It is more commonly used for early-stage cervical cancer in women who wish to preserve fertility.

 

Option C. Conization: While conization (removal of a cone-shaped piece of tissue from the cervix) is a valid treatment for CIN 3, LEEP is often preferred due to its effectiveness and lower morbidity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CIN 3 is best treated with an excisional procedure, with the Loop Electrosurgical Excision Procedure (LEEP) being the procedure of choice.

 

Ref: Page no 328, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: The best method to measure HbA1c is? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ion exchange chromatography

 

Glycated hemoglobin (GHB), reported as hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c), is a biochemical marker that is used routinely in the management of individuals with diabetes mellitus to monitor long-term glycemic control and assess the risk of developing complications.

 

The fraction of hemoglobin glycated, normally about 5%, is proportionate to blood

glucose concentration. Since the half-life of an erythrocyte is typically 60 days, the level of glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) reflects the mean blood glucose concentration over the preceding 6–8 weeks.

 

Four basic types of methods are used most commonly to measure HbA1c: immunoassay, ion-exchange high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), boronate affinity HPLC, and enzymatic assays.

 

Ion-exchange HPLC separates Hb species based on charge differences between HbA1c and other hemoglobins. It is considered as a gold standard for HbA1c analysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoelectric focusing:

  • Function: Separates proteins based on their isoelectric points.
  • Limitation: Not commonly used for HbA1c measurement due to complexity and lower specificity for glycated hemoglobin.

 

Option B. Affinity chromatography:

  • Function: Uses specific binding interactions to separate molecules.
  • Limitation: While effective in some contexts, it is not the most common method for routine HbA1c measurement.

 

Option D. Electrophoresis:

  • Function: Separates proteins based on their size and charge under an electric field.
  • Limitation: Not as specific or reliable for HbA1c measurement compared to ion-exchange HPLC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ion-exchange chromatography is considered the gold standard for measuring HbA1c due to its high accuracy and ability to separate HbA1c from other hemoglobin variants based on charge differences.

questions.text: Identify the audiogram. (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Noise-induced hearing loss

 

The audiogram shows:

 

  • Both air and bone conduction curves are close together (no air-bone gap)
  • Normal hearing at lower frequencies (250 Hz, 500 Hz, 1000 Hz, 2000 Hz)
  • Sharp characteristic dip at 4000 Hz (4 kHz)
  • Bilateral involvement (shown in both red color for right ear and blue color for left ear)
  • This pattern is typically seen in factory workers exposed to loud noises

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Otosclerosis: Shows conductive hearing loss with Carhart's notch at 2000 Hz (2 kHz), not 4000 Hz. Also has significant air-bone gap which is absent here.

Option C. Meniere's disease: Shows sensorineural hearing loss with up-sloping curve affecting low frequencies. Does not show characteristic dip at 4000 Hz.

Option D. Acoustic neuroma: Shows a banana-shaped or trough pattern affecting middle frequencies, with poor speech discrimination. Does not show isolated 4000 Hz dip.

Educational Objective: 

 

Noise-induced hearing loss has a characteristic audiometric pattern with a sharp dip at 4000 Hz, typically bilateral and symmetrical.

 

  • Dip at 2000Hz on BC curve - Otosclerosis
  • Dip at 4000Hz - Noise induced hearing loss
  • Cookie bite audiogram - Congenital hearing loss mostly
  • Trough shaped audiogram - Acoustic neuroma
  • Up-sloping curve with SNHL - Meniere's disease (low frequencies involved)
  • Down-sloping curve with SNHL - Presycusis (high frequency loss) {Presbycusis - age induced hearing loss. Treatment: hearing aid}.
  • High frequency audiometry is used for detecting ototoxicity.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to OPD with swelling in the upper part of the tibia. X-ray revealed periosteal reaction in upper diaphysis of tibia. A histopathological image of the biopsy is given below. Immunohistochemistry was positive for Synaptophysin and MIC-2. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ewing sarcoma

 

Given clinical scenario, immunohistochemistry showing positive for Synaptophysin and MIC-2 with histopath image showing small round blue cells, points to a diagnosis of Ewing’s sarcoma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is an osteoid forming tumor. Patient usually complains of Night pain. But it neither shows small round blue cells on biopsy nor is positive for MIC-2

 

Option C. Metastatic neuroblastoma: Metastatic neuroblastoma also shows Homer wright pseudo rosettes, but it is positive for NSE, PHOX 28.

 

Option D. Osteoclastoma (Giant cell tumor): Osteoclastoma is a benign, locally aggressive bone tumor that is characterized by the presence of multinucleated giant cells on biopsy. It typically affects the epiphysis of long bones and does not present with small round blue cells or positive staining for MIC-2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ewing sarcoma is a small round blue cell tumor commonly occurring in the diaphysis of long bones in adolescents. It is characterized by positive immunohistochemical staining for Synaptophysin and MIC-2 (CD99).

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 2390-2391

questions.text: Match the following poisons and their probable mechanism of action: (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A-2, B-4, C-1, D-3

 

Explanation:

 

A. Zinc chloride:

 

  • Mechanism: Irritant
  • Explanation: Zinc chloride is a chemical compound known to cause erosive esophagitis and irritation to the eyes and mucous membranes.

 

B. Chloral hydrate:

 

  • Mechanism: Stupefying (CNS depressant)
  • Explanation: Chloral hydrate is a central nervous system depressant used historically as a sedative and hypnotic agent.

 

C. Quinine:

 

  • Mechanism: Abortifacient
  • Explanation: Quinine has been used historically to induce abortion, although its use in this context is highly dangerous and not recommended.

 

D. Potassium carbonate:

 

  • Mechanism: Corrosive
  • Explanation: Potassium carbonate is an alkali that has a corrosive action on tissues, causing chemical burns upon contact.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which among the following drugs decreases the serum parathyroid hormone levels? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calcitriol

 

Calcitriol is the active form of vitamin D and plays a crucial role in calcium and phosphate metabolism in the body. It directly acts on vitamin D receptors (VDRs) present in the parathyroid gland, leading to a decrease in the secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH).

 

Mechanism of Action: Calcitriol increases the absorption of calcium and phosphate from the intestines. Elevated levels of calcium in the blood provide negative feedback to the parathyroid glands, which reduces the production of PTH. Additionally, calcitriol directly inhibits the synthesis and secretion of PTH by binding to VDRs in the parathyroid gland. This dual action ensures a reduction in PTH levels, making calcitriol an effective treatment for conditions associated with secondary hyperparathyroidism.

 

Note - Paricalcitol: A synthetic vitamin D receptor (VDR) agonist used to reduce PTH levels in primary hyperparathyroidism. This drug is related to the Cinacalcet, a calcium sensitizer but this act on the calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Risedronate: Risedronate is a bisphosphonate used to treat osteoporosis. It works by inhibiting osteoclast-mediated bone resorption, which can sometimes lead to hypocalcemia. Hypocalcemia can reflexively increase PTH levels, rather than decrease them.

 

Option C. Lithium: Lithium is known to cause unexplained hyperparathyroidism and consequently increase PTH levels. It is one of the common causes of unexplained hyperparathyroidism, making it an unsuitable option for decreasing PTH levels.

 

Option D. Diuretics: Diuretics, particularly loop diuretics, can cause hypocalcemia, which in turn can lead to an increase in PTH levels. Thiazide diuretics can cause hypercalcemia, which might decrease PTH levels, but in this question, "diuretics" is mentioned generally, and loop diuretics are more commonly associated with increased PTH levels due to hypocalcemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Calcitriol, the active form of vitamin D, decreases serum parathyroid hormone levels by increasing calcium absorption from the intestines and directly inhibiting PTH secretion from the parathyroid glands through its action on vitamin D receptors.

choices.text: Subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord

questions.text: A patient has recurrent optic neuritis of both eyes with extensive transverse myelitis. Visual acuity in the right eye is 6/60 and visual acuity in the left eye 6/18. The patient showed a partial response to steroids. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neuromyelitis optica

 

Bilateral optic neuritis with extensive transverse myelitis and partial steroid response is suggestive of NMO-Spectrum disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MS usually causes U/L optic neuritis. LETM (Longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis) not common in MS.

 

Option C. SACD usually affects the posterior column. LETM, optic neuritis not a feature of B12 deficiency.

 

Option D. Neurosyphilis is usually associated with RAPD (U/L Optic neuritis). LETM not common.

 

Educational Objective:

 

WINGERCHUK Criteria for NMO-SD

choices.text: Breech identified for the first-time during delivery is a contraindication for normal delivery
Breech delivery is done in a hospital where a facility for emergency CS is available
Continuous FHR monitoring is required for breech delivery during labor
Should be done by a skilled obstetrician

questions.text: A woman in labour presented to the ER. A vaginal breech delivery was planned for her. What statement regarding the management is false? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Breech identified for the first-time during delivery is a contraindication for normal delivery

 

Explanation:

 

The statement that breech presentation identified for the first time during delivery is a contraindication for normal delivery is false.

 

Breech identified for the first-time during delivery is not automatically a contraindication for a vaginal breech delivery. It is crucial to assess the situation carefully, considering the skill of the obstetrician and the facilities available, but it does not universally rule out the possibility of a vaginal breech delivery.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Breech delivery is done in a hospital where a facility for emergency CS is available: This is correct because the presence of a facility for emergency cesarean section is essential for managing unexpected complications during a breech delivery.

 

Option C. Continuous FHR monitoring is required for breech delivery during labor: This is correct because continuous fetal heart rate monitoring is crucial to detect any signs of fetal distress during a breech delivery.

 

Option D. Should be done by a skilled obstetrician: This is correct as vaginal breech deliveries should be performed by an experienced and skilled obstetrician to manage the potential risks and complications effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Breech presentation identified for the first-time during delivery is not an automatic contraindication for vaginal delivery, provided other criteria are met and facilities are available.

 

Ref: Page no 449, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition.

questions.text: In case of meniscal tear, in which of the following zones the healing is best seen? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Red zone

 

VASCULAR REGIONS IN THE MENISCUS

 

  • Vascular supply to the menisci originates predominantly from the inferior and superior lateral and medial geniculate arteries via the perimeniscal capillary plexus.
  • At birth, the entire meniscus is vascular. Following birth, the menisci become increasingly avascular (decrease in vascularity continues up to age 9 years), so by maturity only the peripheral 10-25% of the tissue is perfused.
  • In adults, only 10-25% of lateral meniscus and 10-30% of medial meniscus is vascular.
  • This gives rise to 3 distinct regions of the menisci: 
    • The peripheral relatively vascularized region called the red-red zone (Zone 1)
    • The completely avascular inner 2/3rd zone is known as the white-white zone (Zone 3)
    • Zone of transition between the two (border of avascular and vascular area), which is called the red-white zone (Zone 2)
       
  • There is a direct relationship between the vascularization and capacity of the tissue to heal, predisposing the white-white zone to permanent posttraumatic and degenerative lesions.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Red-white zone. The red-white zone is the middle third with less vascularization but can heal through sometimes.

 

Option C. White zone. The white-white zone has no blood capillaries at all and therefore, cannot heal. They usually require surgery to remove or cut out the torn portion of the meniscus.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The red zone of the meniscus is the most vascularized zone.
  • Any injury at this zone will heal on its own, without a requirement of surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with post-transcriptional modification? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glycosylation

 

The correct answer is Glycosylation. Glycosylation is a process where sugars are added to proteins or lipids, but it occurs in the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi apparatus, primarily during and after translation, not during post-transcriptional modifications. Post-transcriptional modifications occur to RNA molecules after they have been transcribed from DNA but before they are translated into proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methylation: Methylation in the context of RNA processing involves the addition of a methyl group, often to the 5' end of the RNA as part of the capping process. For example, a 7-methylguanosine cap is added to the 5' end of the RNA to protect it from degradation and assist in ribosome binding during translation.

 

Option B. Endonuclease cleavage: This is part of the splicing process where introns are removed from the pre-mRNA. Endonucleases cut within the nucleotide sequence, helping to remove non-coding sequences (introns) from the RNA transcript.

 

Option C. Capping: This process involves adding a modified guanine nucleotide (7-methylguanosine) to the 5' end of the RNA. This cap protects the RNA from degradation and is essential for the initiation of translation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycosylation is not a post-transcriptional modification. Post-transcriptional modifications include processes like capping, methylation, and splicing, which are critical for the maturation of mRNA before it is translated into protein.

questions.text: Which of the following is the site of lesion in internuclear ophthalmoplegia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Medial Longitudinal Fasciculus

 

Medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF): pair of tracts that interconnect CN VI and CN III nuclei. Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) occurs due to a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), which is responsible for coordinating horizontal eye movements. The command for left gaze originates from the right cerebral cortex and travels to the left paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF). From there, an output goes to the left VI nerve nucleus, which supplies the left lateral rectus muscle, causing abduction. Another output from the left PPRF goes to the right III nerve nucleus via the right MLF, causing the right eye to adduct.

 

If there is a lesion in the right MLF, it leads to the failure of adduction of the right eye. However, the left eye abducts normally. This is the classic presentation of INO.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 6th Nerve nucleus: A lesion here would result in an inability to abduct the eye on the same side, not INO.

 

Option C. Pontine paramedian reticular formation (PPRF): A lesion here would typically affect both the initiation of gaze to the ipsilateral side and horizontal gaze coordination, leading to symptoms different from typical INO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic presentation of internuclear ophthalmoplegia involves a failure of adduction in the affected eye due to a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus. Recognizing this pathway and its role in horizontal eye movement coordination is crucial for diagnosing and understanding the clinical manifestations of INO.

questions.text: Black foot is seen in which poisoning: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Arsenic

 

Blackfoot disease is an endemic peripheral vascular disease found among the inhabitants of a limited area on the southwest coast of Taiwan, where well water with a high concentration of arsenic causes peripheral vascular disease resulting in gangrene.

 

Other options are incorrect as the term Blackfoot disease is used only for arsenic

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Arsenic, cadmium, lead and mercury are the heavy metals which can cause peripheral vascular disease due to chronic poisoning. This leads to general clinical features of peripheral vascular disease (numbness in feet, rest pain etc.).
  • Blackfoot disease is a unique term given to peripheral vascular disease produced by chronic Arsenic poisoning. The name "Blackfoot" refers to the characteristic darkening and gangrene of the feet and lower legs. This ultimately leads to amputation.
  • In peripheral vascular disease caused by other heavy metals, gangrene is not a common manifestation

 

  • Above picture shows Blackfoot disease:

choices.text: Rinne’s test positive , Weber’s test lateralized to left ear
Rinne’s test positive , Weber’s test lateralized to right ear
Rinne’s test negative , Weber’s test lateralized to left ear
Rinne’s test negative , Weber’s test lateralized to right ear

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with bilateral hearing loss with worsened right ear hearing loss. On examination, the doctor diagnose Otosclerosis and recommends stapedectomy as a final resort to the problem. What would be the findings of tuning fork tests based on which the doctor has recommended stapedectomy? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rinne’s test negative, Weber’s test lateralized to right ear

 

  • Rinne’s test negative: Typical of otosclerosis, indicating conductive hearing loss where BC > AC.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to right ear: Indicates that the sound is heard better in the ear with more conductive loss, which matches otosclerosis more severely affecting the right ear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rinne’s test positive, Weber’s test lateralized to left ear:

 

  • Rinne’s test positive: Indicates that air conduction (AC) is better than bone conduction (BC), which is a normal finding and typically not expected in conductive hearing loss like otosclerosis.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to left ear: In a case of unilateral or asymmetric hearing loss, Weber's test lateralizes to the better hearing ear in sensorineural hearing loss and to the poorer ear in conductive hearing loss. This pattern does not fit otosclerosis affecting the right ear more severely.

 

Option B. Rinne’s test positive, Weber’s test lateralized to right ear:

 

  • Rinne’s test positive: Again, indicates normal AC > BC, not typical for otosclerosis.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to right ear: Would suggest either a sensorineural hearing loss on the left ear or less likely conductive loss on the right, which doesn’t match typical otosclerosis findings.

 

Option C. Rinne’s test negative, Weber’s test lateralized to left ear:

 

  • Rinne’s test negative: Indicates that BC > AC, suggesting conductive hearing loss, typical of otosclerosis.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to left ear: Would imply the left ear is either better or has conductive loss, not aligning with greater hearing loss in the right ear due to otosclerosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The combination of a negative Rinne test and Weber test lateralizing to the ear with more hearing loss is indicative of conductive hearing loss in that ear. In otosclerosis, the ossification of the stapes leads to mechanical dysfunction, preventing effective sound transmission, hence a stapedectomy might be recommended to mechanically bypass the ossified stapes and improve hearing.

questions.text: Selenocysteine is present in which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glutathione peroxidase

 

Option B. Glutathione peroxidase: Glutathione peroxidase is an enzyme that contains selenocysteine in its active site. It plays a vital role in protecting cells from oxidative damage by catalyzing the reduction of hydrogen peroxide and lipid hydroperoxides using glutathione as a cofactor.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Glutathione reductase: Glutathione reductase is an enzyme involved in the reduction of oxidized glutathione (GSSG) back to its reduced form (GSH). It does not contain selenocysteine.

 

Option C. Thioredoxin peroxidase: Thioredoxin peroxidase (also known as peroxiredoxins) is a group of thiol-containing proteins involved in breaking down hydrogen peroxide during oxidative stress. It does not contain selenocysteine.

 

Option D. Thioredoxin oxidase: Thioredoxin oxidase is not a known enzyme. There is an enzyme called thioredoxin reductase, which is involved in maintaining the redox state of thioredoxin, but it does not contain selenocysteine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Enzymes which require amino acid selenocysteine at their catalytic site are:
  1. Glutathione Peroxidase
  2. Thioredoxin Reductase
  3. Iodothyronine deiodinase
  • Codon for selenocysteine: UGA
  • This AA is formed by co–translational (during translation) modification (not by post-translational modification).

questions.text: Maternal infection that may lead to teratogenic effect is: [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) All of the above

 

Explanation

 

All listed infections—Chickenpox, Rubella, and CMV (Cytomegalovirus)—can potentially lead to teratogenic effects if a mother contracts them during pregnancy. Here's a brief explanation of how each can impact fetal development:

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Chickenpox: Infection in early pregnancy can lead to congenital varicella syndrome, which includes skin scarring, limb abnormalities, and neurologic disorders.

 

Option B. Rubella: Known for its teratogenic potential if contracted in the first trimester; can cause congenital rubella syndrome, leading to cataracts, deafness, heart defects, and neurological damage.

 

Option C. CMV: The most common viral cause of congenital infections leading to developmental disabilities, including hearing loss, vision loss, and neurodevelopmental disorders.

 

Educational objective :

 

Maternal infection that may lead to teratogenic effect is : TORCH infection

 

  • Toxoplasmosis
  • Other (includes infections such as Syphilis, Varicella-Zoster, Parvovirus B19, and Zika virus)
  • Rubella
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
  • Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV)

 

Note – Now, also includes – Treponema pallidum, HIV, Hep. B viruses

choices.text: X-linked Agammaglobulinemia
Chronic Granulomatous Disease
Severe Combined Immunodeficiency
Chediak-Higashi syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following presents with repeated catalase-positive infections?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic Granulomatous Disease

 

Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) is characterized by repeated catalase-positive infections. The key feature here is the defective NADPH oxidase complex, most commonly due to mutations in the CYBB gene. This defect impairs the neutrophils' ability to produce a respiratory burst, resulting in a killing defect. Patients can phagocytose organisms but cannot effectively kill them, leading to persistent and repeated infections. These infections often result in chronic pus formation, abscesses, and granulomas, which can cause obstructive symptoms in various organ systems.

 

The catalase-positive organisms commonly associated with CGD can be remembered using the mnemonic PACEBAT:

 

P - Pseudomonas aeruginosa

A - Staphylococcus aureus, Aspergillus, Actinomyces israeli

C - Corynebacterium, Candida

E - Enterobacteriaceae (e.g., E. coli)

B - Burkholderia cepacia complex

A - Actinomyces israeli (repeated)

T - Tuberculosis (Mycobacterium tuberculosis)

 

CGD is typically inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern, although autosomal recessive forms exist.

 

Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD), which can be diagnosed with:

 

  • NBT (Nitroblue Tetrazolium) test
  • Dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test, a flow cytometry-based test.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. X-linked Agammaglobulinemia: Incorrect because this condition is characterized by a lack of B cells and immunoglobulins, leading to bacterial infections but not specifically catalase-positive infections. It typically manifests after 4 months of age when maternal antibodies wane.

 

Option C. Severe Combined Immunodeficiency: Incorrect as SCID involves defects in both T and B cells, causing severe infections early in life (within weeks of birth). While it can include both bacterial and fungal infections, it's not specifically associated with catalase-positive organisms.

 

Note - Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) can be caused by:

 

  • ADA deficiency (Adenosine Deaminase deficiency)
  • RAG-1/2 deficiency (Recombination Activating Genes 1 and 2 deficiency)
  • Interleukin-2 receptor gamma (IL-2RG) deficiency

 

Option D. Chediak-Higashi syndrome: Incorrect because although it involves repeated infections due to neutrophil function defects, it's primarily characterized by partial albinism, giant granules in leukocytes, and bleeding tendencies. It's not specifically associated with catalase-positive infections.

 

Note - Chediak-Higashi Syndrome is due to LYST gene defect and presents with a classic triad:

 

  • Oculocutaneous albinism
  • Recurrent infections
  • Neurological abnormalities

 

Giant azurophilic granules within neutrophils are a characteristic feature of Chediak-Higashi Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic Granulomatous Disease is characterized by repeated catalase-positive infections due to defective NADPH oxidase complex, impacting the ability of phagocytes to kill ingested microorganisms.

questions.text: Which of the following tissues are dependent on insulin for glucose uptake? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Muscle and adipose tissues

 

Explanation:

 

GLUT-4 glucose transporter is insulin dependent and is the only GLUT present in muscle and adipose tissues. So, muscles and adipose tissues are totally dependent on Insulin for glucose uptake.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liver: The liver uses GLUT-2 transporters for glucose uptake, which are not insulin-dependent. GLUT-2 allows the liver to take up glucose and store it as glycogen or use it for energy production, independent of insulin.

 

Option B. Pancreas: The pancreas also uses GLUT-2 transporters for glucose uptake, which are not insulin-dependent. In the pancreas, GLUT-2 plays a role in sensing blood glucose levels and regulating insulin secretion.

 

Option D. Placenta: The placenta uses GLUT-1 and GLUT-3 transporters for glucose uptake, which are not insulin-dependent. These transporters facilitate the basal uptake of glucose to support the energy needs of the placenta and fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Tongue fasciculations are seen in: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spinal muscular atrophy

 

Tongue fasciculations are indicative of a lower motor neuron lesion, often associated with disorders that affect the anterior horn cells in the spinal cord or the motor neurons in the brainstem.

 

Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA): This condition is characterized by the degeneration of anterior horn cells in the spinal cord and motor nuclei in the lower brainstem. This degeneration leads to muscle weakness and atrophy, including the muscles of the tongue, resulting in tongue fasciculations. SMA is divided into several types based on the age of onset and severity, but fasciculations are a common feature across these types.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Guillain-Barre syndrome: This is an acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy that primarily affects the peripheral nerves. It does not typically cause fasciculations, as it is more associated with rapidly progressive weakness and areflexia.

 

Option C. Duchenne muscular dystrophy: This is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle degeneration and weakness. It primarily affects the skeletal muscles, and while it leads to muscle weakness, it does not typically cause fasciculations.

 

Option D. Myasthenia gravis: This is an autoimmune disorder affecting the neuromuscular junction. It leads to fluctuating muscle weakness and fatigability but does not involve lower motor neurons or cause fasciculations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tongue fasciculations are a clinical sign associated with spinal muscular atrophy due to the involvement of lower motor neurons

questions.text: For HbA1c sample, the vacutainer used contains which of the following: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) EDTA

 

Hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) is measured to assess long-term glycemic control in diabetic patients. The preferred sample for HbA1c estimation is whole blood, and the anticoagulant used for this is EDTA.

 

  • EDTA (Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) is used because:
    • It prevents coagulation by chelating calcium.
    • It preserves RBC integrity, ensuring accurate measurement of glycosylated hemoglobin.
    • Lavender-top (Purple) vacutainers contain EDTA and are commonly used for HbA1c testing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Warfarin: 

 

  • Warfarin is an anticoagulant used therapeutically, not for blood collection.

 

Option B. Sodium Fluoride:

 

  • Used in gray-top vacutainers, primarily for glucose estimation, as it inhibits glycolysis.
  • Does not preserve RBCs well, so not used for HbA1c.

 

Option D. Heparin:

 

  • Used in green-top vacutainers, primarily for plasma-based tests (e.g., electrolytes, arterial blood gases).
  • Not used for HbA1c, as it does not preserve whole blood effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For HbA1c estimation, EDTA (lavender-top vacutainer) is used because it prevents coagulation while preserving RBC integrity for accurate glycosylated hemoglobin measurement.

 

Vacutainer Vials and Their Uses

 

 

Sequence of blood Drawn - Chalo Bhai, Red yellow Green Light → Go

 

Culture Bottle – Blue – Red – Yellow – Green – Lavender – Grey

questions.text:
A baby is diagnosed with B cell leukemia. All of the following are good prognostic factors except: (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Hyperdiploidy
  2. Age < 1 year
  3. t(9;22)
  4. t(4;11)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 3, 4

 

B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL) is a common type of leukemia in children. Prognostic factors play a crucial role in determining the treatment plan and overall outcomes for patients.

 

2. Age < 1 year: Age less than 1 year is considered a poor prognostic factor in B-ALL. Infants with B-ALL typically have a higher risk of relapse and a poorer response to therapy.

 

3. t(9;22): This translocation involves the Philadelphia chromosome, which is generally associated with poor prognosis in B-ALL. It leads to the formation of the BCR-ABL fusion protein, which is a marker of poor prognosis.

 

4. t(4;11): This translocation is associated with rearrangements of the MLL (Mixed-Lineage Leukemia) gene, which is a poor prognostic factor in B-ALL. It is commonly seen in infants and is associated with a poor outcome.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Hyperdiploidy: Hyperdiploidy (>50 chromosomes) is actually a good prognostic factor in B-ALL. Children with hyperdiploid B-ALL generally have a better response to therapy and a higher overall survival rate.

 

Thus, the factors B (Age < 1 year), C (t(9;22)), and D (t(4;11)) are all poor prognostic indicators, and only A (Hyperdiploidy) is a good prognostic factor.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Causes monofollicular development
Inhibits negative feedback on GnRH
Causes endometrial thinning
Can be used with gonadotropins

questions.text: Which of the following is the incorrect statement regarding clomiphene citrate? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Causes monofollicular development
 

  • Clomiphene citrate is SERM (Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator) that inhibits the negative feedback of estrogen on the hypothalamus, which in turn leads to an increase in LH/FSH, and this helps in the development of multiple follicles in the ovary. Clomiphene is used in the treatment of anovulatory infertility.
  • Due to its anti-estrogenic action over the endometrium, it causes thickening of the cervical mucus and thinning of the endometrium.
  • Sometimes for ovulation induction, gonadotropins can be used with clomiphene, but it has a risk of giving rise to multiple pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inhibits negative feedback on GnRH: This statement is correct. Clomiphene citrate inhibits the negative feedback of estrogen on the hypothalamus, which increases the release of GnRH, and subsequently increases LH and FSH secretion from the pituitary gland.

 

Option C. Causes endometrial thinning: This statement is correct. Clomiphene citrate has an anti-estrogenic effect on the endometrium, which can lead to thinning of the endometrial lining, potentially impacting embryo implantation.

 

Option D. Can be used with gonadotropins: This statement is correct. Clomiphene can be used in combination with gonadotropins for ovulation induction, but this approach increases the risk of multiple pregnancies due to the stimulation of multiple follicles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clomiphene citrate induces ovulation by inhibiting the negative feedback of estrogen on the hypothalamus, leading to increased secretion of gonadotropins and the development of multiple follicles. It can cause endometrial thinning and can be used with gonadotropins, but it does not cause monofollicular development.

questions.text: During development, thymic cells recognizing self-antigens are removed to prevent autoimmunity. Which gene among the following is involved in the process? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) AIRE

 

The above process is called central tolerance and the AIRE (Autoimmune Regulator) protein is necessary for this process.

 

Immature self-reactive T and B lymphocyte clones recognize self-antigens during their maturation in the central lymphoid organs (thymus for T cells, bone marrow for B cells). They are killed or rendered harmless.

 

The removal of self-reacting T lymphocytes in the thymus is called negative selection/ deletion. A protein called AIRE (autoimmune regulator) stimulates expression of some “peripheral tissue-restricted” self-antigens in the thymus and is thus critical for deletion of immature T cells specific for these antigens. Mutations in the AIRE gene are the cause of an autoimmune polyendocrinopathy

 

B cells undergo a process called receptor editing. When developing B cells encounter an antigen, it formulates a change in the receptor that makes the antigen unrecognizable. Self-reacting B cells can also undergo apoptosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NOTCH1: Involved in T cell development but not specifically in the central tolerance process.

 

Option B. RB gene: A tumor suppressor gene involved in regulating the cell cycle, not in immune tolerance.

 

Option C. CPK gene: Not relevant to the process of central tolerance or immune regulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The AIRE gene is crucial for central tolerance in the thymus, preventing autoimmunity by ensuring the deletion of self-reactive T cells.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No. 397-398

choices.text: Increased tone of the pharyngeal muscles worsens obstruction
Fall of oxygen saturation triggers waking episodes at night
Episodes of apnea increase stress on the heart
Hypoxemia stimulates respiratory effort

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented to OPD with complaints of excessive daytime sleepiness, and his wife also complains that he snores a lot at night during sleep. Which of the following is incorrect regarding his condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased tone of the pharyngeal muscles worsens obstruction

 

The patient's symptoms suggest obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), a condition characterized by repeated episodes of partial or complete obstruction of the upper airway during sleep, leading to disrupted sleep and decreased oxygen levels.

 

 Increased tone of the pharyngeal muscles worsens obstruction: This statement is incorrect. In obstructive sleep apnea, the problem is actually due to the decreased tone or flaccidity of the pharyngeal muscles during sleep, which causes the airway to collapse and obstruct. Increased tone of these muscles would actually help keep the airway open.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fall of oxygen saturation triggers waking episodes at night: This statement is correct. During episodes of apnea, the blood oxygen levels drop, leading to hypoxemia. This triggers arousal from sleep to restore normal breathing, leading to fragmented sleep and excessive daytime sleepiness.

 

Option C. Episodes of apnea increase stress on the heart: This statement is correct. The repetitive episodes of apnea and hypoxemia increase the work of breathing and intrathoracic pressure changes, which can increase stress on the heart, leading to potential cardiovascular complications such as hypertension and heart failure.

 

Option D. Hypoxemia stimulates respiratory effort: This statement is correct. Hypoxemia (low blood oxygen levels) and hypercapnia (high carbon dioxide levels) stimulate the brain's respiratory centers, increasing respiratory effort to overcome the obstruction and restore normal breathing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In obstructive sleep apnea, decreased tone or flaccidity of the pharyngeal muscles during sleep leads to airway collapse and obstruction. Increased muscle tone would help keep the airway open and is not a cause of obstruction in this condition.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rectal temperature probe


The image displays a rectal temperature probe, a device used for continuous and accurate core temperature monitoring. It is inserted rectally, allowing healthcare providers to monitor a patient’s body temperature closely, particularly in critical care or perioperative settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NAVA catheter:  Neurally Adjusted Ventilatory Assist (NAVA) is a mode of mechanical ventilation. The NAVA catheter is used to detect electrical activity in the diaphragm, which helps synchronize ventilation with the patient’s spontaneous respiratory effort.

 

 

Option C. Swan-Ganz catheter:  Also known as a pulmonary artery catheter, the Swan-Ganz catheter is used for right heart catheterization. It measures various hemodynamic parameters, including pulmonary artery pressure, cardiac output, and mixed venous oxygen saturation.

 

Option D. CVP transducer:  A Central Venous Pressure (CVP) transducer is used to monitor central venous pressure. It is connected to a central venous line and a monitor, primarily in critical care settings, to assess venous return and fluid status.

 

 

Educational Objective:


A rectal temperature probe provides accurate core temperature monitoring and is especially useful in critical care or during surgical procedures.

choices.text: Varenicline comes with a black box warning of cardiovascular death
There should be a 15-minute gap between nicotine gum and coffee/soda/acidic food as they decrease its absorption
Nicotine chewing gum is better for constant use as it gives 25% higher blood level than lozenges

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding nicotine substitution therapy? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) There should be a 15-minute gap between nicotine gum and coffee/soda/acidic food as they decrease its absorption.

 

 Acidic beverages can interfere with nicotine gum's absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preferably given by gastrointestinal route: Incorrect. NRT is not given via the gastrointestinal route. Nicotine in NRT is absorbed either through buccal mucosa or skin.

 

Option B. Varenicline comes with a black box warning of cardiovascular death: Incorrect. Varenicline doesn’t come with this black box warning.

 

Option D. Nicotine chewing gum is better for constant use as it gives 25% higher blood level than lozenges: Incorrect. Choice between gum and lozenges depends on individual preference, not blood levels.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) is an effective method to assist in smoking cessation. It is used to relieve craving for tobacco by substituting nicotine in tobacco with nicotine in safer forms. Various preparations include nicotine gums, nicotine lozenges, nicotine patch, nicotine spray and nicotine inhaler. Nicotine gum's absorption can be affected by acidic beverages, so it's advised to avoid them shortly before or while using the gum.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 684.

questions.text:
A pregnant woman at 36 weeks gestation is found to have high blood pressure recording and a urine protein of 3+. Concomitant presence of which of the following symptoms would make you suspect imminent eclampsia? 

 

  1. Headache
  2. Blurred vision
  3. Persistent pedal edema
  4. Epigastric pain
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4

 

Explanation:

 

Imminent eclampsia is indicated by the presence of severe symptoms in a patient with preeclampsia. The following symptoms are particularly concerning and suggest the risk of progression to eclampsia:

 

  • Headache
  • Blurred vision
  • Epigastric pain
  • Vomiting (though not listed in the options)

 

Key Points:

 

1. Headache: Severe, persistent headache is a sign of central nervous system involvement.

 

2. Blurred vision: Visual disturbances such as blurred vision or seeing spots are due to cerebral or retinal vasospasm.

 

4. Epigastric pain: Pain in the epigastric or right upper quadrant can indicate hepatic involvement, such as stretching of the Glisson capsule due to liver swelling.

 

Other symptoms not specifically listed:

 

  • Vomiting: This can also be a sign of worsening preeclampsia.

 

Other Option:

 

3. Persistent pedal edema : While edema can be present in preeclampsia, it is not a specific indicator of imminent eclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a pregnant woman with preeclampsia, the presence of headache, blurred vision, and epigastric pain indicates imminent eclampsia and necessitates immediate intervention with prophylactic magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) and planning for delivery to prevent the onset of seizures.

 

Ref: Williams text book of obstetrics 26th edition Pg 1840, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics pg 261,262

questions.text: Which of the following is not a true statement regarding telomerase? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Involved in DNA repair

 

Telomerase is not primarily involved in DNA repair. While telomere maintenance can influence genome stability and prevent end-to-end chromosome fusions, telomerase itself does not play a direct role in the classical DNA repair pathways such as base excision repair, nucleotide excision repair, mismatch repair, or double-strand break repair.

 

Telomerase is a specialized enzyme that adds repetitive nucleotide sequences to the ends of chromosomes (telomeres) in eukaryotic cells. Its primary function is to maintain the length and stability of chromosomes by compensating for the loss of DNA that occurs during cell division.

 

Additional Information:

 

  • Telomeres are repetitive non-coding DNA sequences at the ends of chromosomes that protect them from degradation and prevent chromosomal fusion.
  • Telomerase activity declines with age, leading to the progressive shortening of telomeres and eventual cell senescence or apoptosis.
  • In many cancer cells, telomerase activity is upregulated, allowing these cells to bypass senescence and continue dividing indefinitely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Has reverse transcriptase activity: Telomerase contains an RNA component that serves as a template for adding telomeric repeats to the chromosome ends. The enzyme uses this RNA template to synthesize DNA, acting as a reverse transcriptase.

 

Option B. Present only in Eukaryotes: Telomerase is found only in eukaryotic cells because prokaryotic chromosomes are typically circular and do not have telomeres that require maintenance.

 

Option C. Maintains the chromosome length: Telomerase extends the telomeres, preventing their shortening during DNA replication and thus maintaining chromosome length and stability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Telomerase is an enzyme with reverse transcriptase activity, present only in eukaryotes, and is crucial for maintaining chromosome length by adding telomeric repeats. It is not directly involved in DNA repair.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents to the emergency room with a fractured forearm and says she tripped and fell. On examination, you notice multiple cigarette burns on her forearm. What will you do next?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Conduct a thorough examination

 

In cases of suspected child abuse, the first and most important step is to conduct a thorough physical examination to assess the extent of any injuries and identify any additional signs of abuse. Noticing multiple cigarette burns on the child’s forearm raises strong suspicion of physical abuse, and documenting all findings accurately is critical. After the physical examination, it is essential to follow up with a psychiatric evaluation and ensure the child's safety. In cases of confirmed or suspected abuse, further steps will include informing child protective services or relevant authorities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Seek a social worker’s help: While involving a social worker is important, it is not the immediate next step. The priority should be a thorough physical examination to assess the injuries.

 

Option C. Inform higher authorities immediately: Reporting to authorities is necessary, but only after conducting a detailed examination and collecting the necessary evidence.

 

Option D. Inform your colleagues: Although consulting colleagues might be helpful, the first step is a thorough examination to gather crucial details for further action.

 

Educational Objective:


When encountering a suspected case of child abuse, the first step should be a comprehensive physical examination to document and evaluate the injuries, followed by appropriate reporting and interventions to ensure the child's safety.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Due to increasing mammography, there occurs over-diagnosis of breast carcinoma
  2. Colon cancer screening is done by digital rectal examination
  3. Oral cancer screening is done by visual inspection
  4. Cervix cancer screening is done by a pap smear
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3, 4

 

Statements 1, 3 and 4 are true.

 

1. Due to increasing mammography, there occurs over-diagnosis of breast carcinoma: This is true. Mammography is an essential tool in the early detection of breast cancer, but it has been associated with over-diagnosis. As a result, some women might receive unnecessary treatment for non-life-threatening tumors.

 

2. Oral cancer screening is done by visual inspection: This is true. Visual inspection of the oral cavity can detect precancerous lesions or early signs of oral cancer. Regular dental check-ups often include a visual check for signs of oral cancer.

 

3. Cervix cancer screening is done by a pap smear: This is true. A Pap smear (or Pap test) is a procedure to test for cervical cancer in women. The test involves collecting cells from the cervix to be examined under a microscope to detect abnormalities that can turn into cervical cancer.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Colon cancer screening is done by digital rectal examination: This statement is not entirely accurate. While a digital rectal examination (DRE) can detect some abnormalities or tumors in the rectum, it is not the primary method for colon cancer screening. The primary methods for colon cancer screening include fecal occult blood testing, sigmoidoscopy, and colonoscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Screening for common cancers using relatively non-invasive tests is expected to lead to early diagnosis, allow more conservative surgical therapies with decreased morbidity, and potentially improve surgical cure rates and overall survival rates.
  2. Current American Cancer Society guidelines advocate colon cancer screening for the average-risk population beginning at age 50 years. Recommended procedures include yearly fecal occult blood testing (FOBT)/fecal immunohistochemical testing (FIT), flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 years, or FOBT/FIT and flexible sigmoidoscopy.
  3. Visual inspection of the oral cavity has been widely used for screening oral cancer. The target population for oral cancer screening includes those aged 30 years and older who use tobacco and/or alcohol. Advantages of visual inspection include its feasibility, safety, acceptability, accuracy to detect oral precancerous and cancerous lesions, and efficacy and cost-effectiveness in reducing oral cancer mortality.
  4. Pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer. Screening should begin at age 21 years. For women aged between 21-29 years, screening should be done every 3 years with Pap smear examination. For women aged between 30-65 years, screening should be done every 5 years with both HPV and the Pap co-test.
  5. Using mammography as a routine screening tool in women has been reported to reduce mortality from breast cancer. The United Kingdom recently established an independent expert panel to estimate the benefits and harms associated with screening women in its national screening program. The panel estimated that breast screening resulted in a 20% reduction in breast cancer mortality. The panel also noted over-diagnosis of breast carcinoma but concluded that breast screening confers significant benefits and should be continued.

choices.text: To hold and support the specimen slide
To regulate the amount of light reaching the specimen
To adjust the focus and clarity of the image

questions.text: What is the primary function of the condenser in a compound microscope? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To regulate the amount of light reaching the specimen

 

The condenser in a compound microscope is a crucial component located within or below the stage (sub-stage). Its primary function is to gather and concentrate light from the microscope's illuminator and direct it into a light cone that focuses on the specimen.

 

Condenser Function:

 

  • Light Regulation: The condenser focuses and concentrates the light onto the specimen to ensure optimal illumination, which is critical for viewing the specimen clearly.
  • Improving Image Quality: By regulating and directing the light precisely, the condenser enhances the contrast and clarity of the image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To magnify the specimen image: Magnification is achieved by the objective lenses and eyepiece, not by the condenser.

 

Option B. To hold and support the specimen slide: The stage is the part of the microscope that holds and supports the specimen slide, not the condenser.

 

Option D. To adjust the focus and clarity of the image: Focus adjustment is achieved using the coarse and fine adjustment knobs, not the condenser.

 

Parts of Microscope

questions.text: How long should elective surgery be deferred for a patient who had cough and fever, after he has recovered from COVID-19, and has not required any hospitalization?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 6 weeks

 

Elective surgery deferral based on respiratory disease severity and COVID-19 recovery:

 

  • 4 weeks: For an asymptomatic patient with mild respiratory symptoms.
  • 6 weeks: For a symptomatic patient who did not need hospital treatment.
  • 8 weeks: For a symptomatic patient who was hospitalized in the ward.
  • 12 weeks: For a patient who was admitted to the intensive care unit due to respiratory infection.

 

Application:

 

  • As this patient was symptomatic but did not need hospitalization, elective surgery can be deferred for 6 weeks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 8-10 weeks: This timeline is recommended for symptomatic patients who were hospitalized in the ward, which does not apply to this patient.

 

Option C. 12 weeks: This timeline is for patients who were admitted to the intensive care unit due to a respiratory infection, which also does not apply to this patient.

 

Option D. 4 weeks: This timeline is for asymptomatic patients with mild respiratory symptoms, which is not the case for this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Elective surgery should be deferred for 6 weeks in a patient who had cough and fever due to COVID-19 but did not require hospitalization. This ensures sufficient recovery time to reduce perioperative risks.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 2423

questions.text: What condition can lead to the characteristic waveform on capnography displayed by a patient under general anesthesia as observed on the ET CO2 monitor? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bronchospasm

 

Shark Fin appearance seen in bronchospasm due to anaphylaxis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Malignant hyperthermia:

 

 

Option C. Rebreathing:

 

 

Option D. Accidental extubation

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Shark Fin appearance seen in bronchospasm is due to anaphylaxis.

questions.text: Fructosamine (which is used for assessing long term glycemic control in a person with hemolysis) is a glycated product of: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Albumin

 

Fructosamine is a compound formed when glucose binds to serum albumin, which is the most abundant protein in the blood. This glycated product provides an indicator of long-term glycemic control because it reflects the average blood glucose levels over the previous 2 to 3 weeks. Since it is primarily formed from the glycation of albumin, option d (Albumin) is the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycosaminoglycan refers to a different type of compound, glycosaminoglycans, which are long, linear polysaccharides found in connective tissues.

 

Option B. Urea is a waste product removed by the kidneys and is not involved in fructosamine formation.

 

Option C. Fructose is a sugar but is not directly related to the formation of fructosamine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose can be attached to proteins, albumin, and also to RBCs forming HbA1c. Fructosamine is term used for all the glycated proteins including glycated albumin.

 

 

 

In hemolysis patient, HbA1c analysis cannot be done because it will be falsely decreased due to damage to RBCs and loss of hemoglobin. So, fructosamine determination is used for these patients.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is the causative agent associated with in this case? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pure red cell aplasia

 

  • The provided picture displays the typical appearance of a slapped cheek  due to cutaneous vasodilatation, indicating a probable case of erythema infectiosum.
  • This condition is caused by the Parvovirus B19.
  • Parvovirus B19 is linked to pure red cell aplasia.

 

MANIFESTATIONS OF PARVOVIRUS B19

 

1. Fetus

  • Severe anemia (transient aplastic crises)
  • Pure red cell aplasia
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Hydrops fetalis
  • Spontaneous abortion

 

 

2. Children/adults

  • Fifth disease, erythema infectiosum, slapped cheek fever
  • 7−10-day incubation
  • Nonspecific “flu-like” symptoms followed by raised, indurated facial rash (Slapped cheek)

 

 

3. Adults

  • Rash and arthralgias (involves wrist most often) are due to immune complexes in the skin and joints.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gingivostomatitisis can be caused by Herpes virus.

 

Option C. Molluscum contagiosum is an infection caused by a poxvirus 

 

Option D. Kaposi sarcoma is caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19, the causative agent of erythema infectiosum, is associated with pure red cell aplasia, particularly in individuals with underlying hemolytic disorders.
