questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with the blurring of vision. Urine examination showed proteinuria. Fundus examination showed dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and cotton wool spots. Histopathology of the kidney was as shown below. What is your diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease

 

Histopathological image shows acellular periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive nodules suggestive of nodular glomerulosclerosis/intercapillary glomerulosclerosis seen in Kimmelstiel Wilson disease, which occurs in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

 

These lesions are specific for type 1 diabetes (juvenile onset diabetes) or islet cell antibody-positive diabetes mellitus.

 

The pathologic changes consist of one or more nodules in a few or many glomeruli. Nodule is an ovoid or spherical, laminated, hyaline, acellular mass located within a lobule of the glomerulus.

 

The nodules are surrounded peripherally by glomerular capillary loops which may have normal or thickened GBM. The nodules are PAS-positive and contain lipid and fibrin. These nodular lesions are frequently accompanied by prominent accumulations of hyaline material in capillary loops (“fibrin caps”) or adherent to Bowman's capsules (“capsular drops”).

 

 

As the nodular lesions enlarge, they compress the glomerular capillaries and obliterate the glomerular tuft. As a result of glomerular and arteriolar involvement, renal ischemia occurs leading to tubular atrophy and interstitial fibrosis and grossly small, contracted kidney.

 

Renal failure is the second common cause of death in diabetes mellitus, the first being myocardial infarction.

 

Diabetic nephropathy encompasses 4 types of renal lesions in diabetes mellitus:

 

1. Diabetic glomerulosclerosis (Diffuse/ Nodular)

 

  1. Diffuse lesions are characterized by diffuse involvement of the glomeruli showing thickening of the GBM and diffuse increase in the mesangial matrix with mild proliferation of mesangial cells and exudative lesions (fibrin caps and capsular drops)
  2. Nodular lesion (Kimmelstiel-Wilson Lesion) is characterized by one or more hyaline nodules within the lobules of glomeruli, surrounded peripherally by glomerular capillaries with thickened walls.

 

 

2.  Vascular lesions – Hyaline arterioslerosis

Morphology

 

 

3. Diabetic pyelonephritis – Papillary necrosis / Necrotizing papillitis

 

4. Tubular lesions (Armanni-Ebstein lesions).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal amyloidosis: Amyloidosis presents with amyloid deposits, typically visualized using Congo red stain, which is different from the PAS-positive nodules seen in Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease.

 

Option B. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS): FSGS is characterized by segmental scarring of some glomeruli and does not present with the diffuse nodular glomerulosclerosis observed in Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease.

 

Option D. Lupus nephritis: Lupus nephritis involves immune complex deposition, which leads to a different set of histological changes, including "wire loop" lesions, which are not present in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease, a specific form of diabetic nephropathy, is characterized by PAS-positive nodules within the glomeruli, often associated with type 1 diabetes mellitus.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No. 2206

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented with fever, thrombocytopenia, and hematuria. The mother tells you that the baby also suffered from bloody diarrhea a few days back. Which is likely microorganism to be isolated from the stool sample? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) E. coli O157:H7

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) based on the triad of:

 

  • Hematuria
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • History of bloody diarrhea

 

E. coli O157:H7, also known as Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (STEC) or Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC), is the most common causative organism of HUS, particularly in children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Shigella flexneri

 

  • Incorrect because while it can cause bloody diarrhea, it is more commonly associated with reactive arthritis rather than HUS.
  • Does not typically cause the combination of hematuria and thrombocytopenia.

 

Option C. Salmonella enteritis

 

  • Incorrect as it is primarily associated with osteomyelitis in patients with sickle cell disease.
  • Not typically associated with HUS.

 

Option D. Aeromonas

 

  • Incorrect as it typically causes simple diarrhea without the complications of HUS.
  • Does not produce Shiga toxin, which is responsible for HUS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

E. coli O157:H7 is the most common cause of Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome in children, typically presenting with bloody diarrhea followed by the triad of hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1

 

 The correct matching is:

 

  • Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is a major tumor marker for hepatocellular carcinoma. It's an oncofetal protein that is normally produced during fetal development but can be elevated in certain cancers, particularly hepatocellular carcinoma.
  • Beta-hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) is the primary tumor marker for choriocarcinoma. This marker is normally produced during pregnancy but is pathologically elevated in choriocarcinoma, a malignant trophoblastic tumor.
  • Catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine, dopamine) are elevated in pheochromocytoma, which is a tumor of the adrenal medulla that secretes excessive amounts of these hormones.
  • Calcitonin is the characteristic tumor marker for medullary thyroid carcinoma, which arises from parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland that produce this hormone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tumor Markers

questions.text: Sign of effective neonatal resuscitation is: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased heart rate

 

The best indicator of successful newborn resuscitation is a rise in heart rate. Based on heart rate, the response to newborn resuscitation is evaluated at different stages.

 

  • If the heart rate is under 100, PPV is given, SPO2 is monitored, and sufficient breathing is guaranteed.
  • Chest compressions are started over the lower portion of the sternum at a pace of 90 compressions per minute if the heart rate is below 60. The ventilation to compression ratio is 3 to 1.
  • IV epinephrine is administered if the heart rate is still below 60 despite effective compressions and breathing.


 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colour change: Colour change is not a sign of effective resuscitation.

 

Option B. Bilateral air entry: this feature is checked when we are thinking of pneumothorax or severe pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best indicator of successful newborn resuscitation is a rise in heart rate.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is NOT transmitted by sandflies? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Trench fever

 

Trench fever is transmitted by lice and caused by Bartonella quintana.

 

Points to remember about Sandfly - 

 

  • Sandfly cannot fly; it hops
  • Sandfly rests in cracks and crevices of walls
  • Insecticide of choice: 

 

DDT - 2 rounds of spray per year; Spray up to 6 feet height on walls; 

 

If DDT–resistant, use BHC 

 

  • Sandfly is the vector of:
    • Visceral Leishmaniasis (Kala azar) (by Female Phlebotamus argentipes)
    • Cutaneous Leishmaniasis (Oriental Sore) & Mucocutaneous Leishmaniasis (by Phlebotamus papatasi & Phlebotamus sergenti)
    • Sandfly Fever
    • Oroya Fever
  • Sandflies inject the infective stage, metacyclic promastigotes, during blood meals.

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vectors and Diseases Transmitted

questions.text:
A pregnant woman presented with total ophthalmoplegia, pulsatile proptosis of the right eye, retroorbital pain accompanied with fever and headache. On examination, fundus and BP were normal. Which of the following structures are involved?

 

  1. Abducens nerve
  2. Oculomotor nerve
  3. Internal carotid artery
  4. Cavernous sinus
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

The clinical presentation of pulsatile proptosis, retroorbital pain, fever, and headache in a pregnant woman suggests the involvement of multiple cranial structures, primarily those associated with the cavernous sinus, a critical venous sinus at the base of the brain that acts as a conduit for venous blood drainage from the brain and eye. This constellation of symptoms and signs is indicative of cavernous sinus thrombosis (CST), a severe and potentially life-threatening condition.

 

  • Cavernous sinus thrombosis (CST) is a septic thrombus formed in the cavernous sinus due to the spread of infection from sinuses, teeth, ears, nose, and skin of the face.
  • Symptoms include fever, severe headache, supraorbital pain, seizures, and edema in the mastoid region.
  • Eye signs include proptosis, chemosis, and diplopia due to ophthalmoplegia from the involvement of oculomotor (CN-III), trochlear (CN-IV), and abducens nerve (CN-VI).
  • Absence of corneal sensation due to the involvement of the ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve (CN-V1)
  • Ipsilateral ptosis, dilated pupil, and absence of direct and consensual pupillary right reflex due to oculomotor nerve palsy.
  • Pulsatile proptosis occurs with the involvement of the internal carotid artery.
  • Brain magnetic resonance imaging or magnetic resonance venography should be done urgently for diagnosis.
  • Management of CST includes intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics, analgesics, anti-inflammatory drugs, and anticoagulants.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Dr. Rathi, an obstetrician in a suburban Indian clinic, was counseling Mrs. Mehta, a software engineer, on nutritional needs during pregnancy. Mrs. Mehta has a sedentary desk job and is entering her second trimester. The doctor emphasized the significance of an appropriate caloric intake to ensure both maternal and fetal health. Given her lifestyle and the stage of pregnancy, by how much should Mrs. Mehta ideally increase her daily caloric consumption? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 350 kcal/day

 

The suggested daily calorie intake for a pregnant woman in a sedentary occupation should be raised by approximately 350 calories.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pregnancy Additional Energy Requirements:
    • +350 kcal/day
  • Lactation Additional Energy Requirements:
    • 0-6 m: +600 kcal/day
    • 6-12 m: +520 kcal/day

questions.text: A 9-year-old child presents to your clinic with the following deformity of the right arm. Which is the most likely fracture leading to such a defect? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Supracondylar fracture

 

SUPRACONDYLAR FRACTURE OF THE HUMERUS

 

  • This is one of the most serious fractures in childhood as it is often associated with complications. 
  • Most common elbow fractures – 50-70%
  • Mechanism:
    • The fracture is caused by a fall on an out-stretched hand. 
    • As the hand strikes the ground, the elbow is forced into hyperextension resulting in fracture of the humerus above the condyles. 
  • Pathoanatomy:
    • The fracture line extends transversely through the distal metaphysis of humerus just above the condyles. 
  • Types:
    • A supracondylar fracture may be of extension or flexion type, depending upon the displacement of the distal fragment. 
    • The extension type is the commoner (98%) of the two. 
    • In this, the distal fragment is extended (tilted backwards) in relation to the proximal fragment. 
    • In the flexion type, the distal fragment is flexed (tilted forwards) in relation to the proximal fragment. 
  • Treatment:
    • Closed reduction and cast
    • If conservative management fails or if fracture is displaced, closed reduction and K-wire fixation is done.
  • Complications:
    • Malunion – most common 
    • Posteromedial displacement develops cubitus varus/gunstock deformity
    • Nerve injury: Anterior interosseous nerve most commonly injured followed by median, radial and ulnar nerves – transient neuropraxia occurs 
    • Vessel injury: Brachial artery 
    • Volkmann’s ischemia and compartment syndrome 
    • Elbow stiffness 
    • Myositis ossificans 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colle’s fracture. Colles fracture is fracture of lower end of radius at its corti-cocancellous junction mostly occurring in post-menopausal osteoporotic elderly women; as a result of fall on outstretched hand, with wrist in extension. It is one of the most common fractures in elderly. It is commonly associated with dinner fork deformity. It is treated successfully with a hand-shaking cast. Finger stiffness is the most common complication. Malunion is the 2nd most common complication, leading to dinner fork deformity. Colle’s fracture is the commonest cause of sudeck’s dystrophy in the upper limb. 

 

 

Option B. Lateral epicondyle fracture. Lateral humeral condyle fractures are the second most commonly encountered elbow fractures after supracondylar fractures in the pediatric age group. These fractures are intra-articular and are prone to displacement owing to the attachment of the forearm extensor muscles on the lateral condyle. Due to this, they can produce various complications, including elbow deformity, if not appropriately managed. Displaced fractures are at a higher risk of non-union. Malunion, cubitus varus, avascular necrosis, and post-operative infection are recognized complications following surgery. The most common mechanism is a fall on the outstretched hand with the elbow in extension and the forearm in supination. Fractures with <2mm displacement can have conservative treatment. The indications of surgery are fracture displacement >2 mm and articular surface incongruency. Closed reduction and percutaneous fixation are options.

 

 

Option C. Medial epicondyle fracture. A medial epicondyle fracture is an avulsion injury of the attachment of the common flexors of the forearm. The injury is usually extra-articular but can be sometimes associated with an elbow dislocation. Medial epicondyle fractures are common and account for 10% of all elbow fractures in children. They occur between the ages of 7-15 years. They are usually a result from an avulsion injury caused by a valgus stress at the elbow and contraction of the flexor muscles. Potential complications include medial elbow instability and nonunion.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image shows a gunstock deformity i.e., cubitus varus deformity of the elbow after malunion of the supracondylar fracture of the humerus.

questions.text: Match the following: (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. i-3, ii-4, iii-1, iv-2 

 

i. Mummification - Image 3. It is a method of embalming the dead body. It occurs in the absence of moisture in the air and continuous action of dry or warmed air.

 

ii. Adipocere - Image 4. It forms under warm and humid weather due to hydrolysis of lipids.

 

iii. Marbling - Image 1. In marbling, blood vessels are visible on the skin as greenish-black streaks and eventually results in skin discoloration ranging from green to black, due to the formation of sulphmethemoglobin, which starts in 24 hours and becomes prominent in 36-48 hours.

 

iv. Postmortem lividity - Image 2. Livor mortis, also known as postmortem hypostasis or postmortem lividity, is a passive process of blood accumulating within the blood vessels in the dependent parts of the body as a result of gravity, causing a discoloration of the skin that varies from pink to dark purplish.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mummification: Occurs in dry or warm environments, preserving the body by desiccation.
  • Adipocere: Forms in warm, humid conditions through the hydrolysis of lipids, leading to a waxy transformation of body fat.
  • Marbling: Blood vessels become visible as greenish-black streaks due to sulphmethemoglobin formation, appearing within 24 hours and becoming prominent by 36-48 hours.
  • Postmortem Lividity: Blood accumulates in dependent body parts due to gravity, causing discoloration from pink to dark purple.

questions.text: A clinician is conducting a study on the occurrence of a rare disease within a specific population over a certain time period. The disease cases occur independently, and the average rate of occurrence is constant. Which statistical distribution best represents the likelihood of observing a specific number of disease cases within this defined time period? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Poisson distribution

 

Poisson Distribution

 

  • It is a ‘discrete probability distribution’ that expresses the ‘probability of a number of events occurring in a fixed period of time’ (if these events occur with a known average rate and independently of the time since the last event).
  • It can also be used for the number of events in other specified intervals such as distance, area or volume.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Binomial distribution is used for those events which can only have two possible results given as yes or no / success or failure. It is usually done for finite number of events unlike Poisson’s distribution.

 

Option B. Gaussian distribution and Option D. Normal distribution is the distribution of values of a quantitative variable such that they are symmetric with respect to a middle value with same mean, median and mode, and then the frequencies taper off rapidly and symmetrically on both sides – ‘bell shaped distribution’.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Poisson distribution is used to model the number of rare disease cases occurring independently in a fixed period of time.

choices.text: Start antibiotics and send samples for culture

questions.text: A patient who is intubated had an X-ray done. The radiograph is shown below. What is the next step in the management of this patient? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ultrasound guided aspiration

 

Chest radiograph shows Unilateral Left pleural effusion. In the absence of suspicion for transudative effusion, thoracocentesis is indicated in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suction with percussion physiotherapy is recommended in suspected collapse due to mucus plugging etc.

 

Option B. Antibiotics are initiated if suspicion of severe CAP is present.

 

Option C. Chest physiotherapy is given to reduce collapse and pulmonary rehabilitation.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the grip in the image given below: (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pawlik grip

 

  • The Leopold's third manuever is also called the Pawlik's grip.
  • It is performed by grasping with the thumb and fingers, the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis. If the presenting part is not engaged, a movable mass will be felt.

 

Obstetric grips (Leopold maneuvers):

 

  1. Fundal grip (1st Leopold)
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Lateral/umbilical grip (2nd Leopold)
  3. ﻿﻿﻿1st pelvic grip / Pawlik grip (3rd Leopold)
  4. 2nd pelvic grip (4th Leopold)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Second Pelvic grip: This is incorrect. The second pelvic grip, also known as the fourth Leopold maneuver, is used to determine the degree of fetal descent and engagement.

 

Option B. Abdominal grip: This term is not specific to any of the Leopold maneuvers and is not used in this context.

 

Option D. Fundal grip: This is the first Leopold maneuver, used to determine the fetal part located in the fundus of the uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Pawlik grip (third Leopold maneuver) involves grasping the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis to assess the engagement of the presenting part of the fetus.

 

Ref: Page no 89-90, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: Central line insertion
Arterial line insertion

questions.text: The given set of instruments are used in? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Airway management

 

Explanation:

 

The instruments shown in the image are part of an airway cart. The equipment typically found in an airway cart is designed for managing the airway during anesthesia or in emergency situations. The contents of the airway cart usually include:

 

  • Laryngoscope: A device used to obtain a view of the vocal folds and the glottis, which is essential for endotracheal intubation.
  • Tracheal tubes of various sizes: These tubes are used to secure the airway by passing through the trachea.
  • Masks: Various types of masks to deliver oxygen or anesthetic gases.
  • Laryngeal mask airways (LMA): A device placed over the laryngeal inlet to provide ventilation.
  • Flexible fiberoptic intubation equipment: Used for intubation in difficult airway situations.
  • Retrograde intubation equipment: Tools used for intubation when conventional methods fail.
  • Front of neck access equipment: Devices for surgical airway access.
  • Equipment required for emergency invasive airway access: Tools needed for emergency tracheostomy or cricothyrotomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central line insertion: This procedure requires different instruments such as central venous catheters, guidewires, dilators, and sterile drapes.

 

Option B. Arterial line insertion: This involves the use of arterial catheters, guidewires, and transducers, not typically found in an airway cart.

 

Option D. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR): CPR primarily requires defibrillators, chest compression devices, and basic airway management tools like bag-valve masks (BVM), but not the comprehensive set shown for airway management.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The instruments in an airway cart are specifically designed for various procedures involved in airway management, including intubation and emergency airway access.

choices.text: Neurodegeneration with Brain Iron Accumulation

questions.text: Which of the following does not show both hyperkinetic and hypokinetic movements? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Huntington's chorea

 

Huntington's chorea is characterized by hyperkinetic movements such as chorea but does not typically present with hypokinetic movements.

 

Huntington's chorea presents with a classic triad of abnormal movements (chorea), dementia, and psychiatric manifestations. It also has a strong family history due to its inherited nature.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Parkinson's disease:  Parkinson's disease shows both tremors (hyperkinetic) and bradykinesia (hypokinetic).

 

Option B. Wilson's disease:  Wilson's disease can present with a combination of movement disorders.

 

Option C. Neurodegeneration with Brain Iron Accumulation:  Neurodegeneration with Brain Iron Accumulation also shows mixed movement disorders.

 

Educational Objective:


Huntington's chorea primarily presents with hyperkinetic movements and not hypokinetic movements.

questions.text: Medial lemniscus is a continuation of which of the following structures? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Fasciculus gracilis

 

Medial lemniscus is a continuation of fasciculus gracilis as well as fasciculus cuneatus.

 

Posterior column-medial lemniscal pathway:

 

In the dorsal horn, first-order axons carrying proprioception vibration  and two point discrimination sensations continue their upward journey as the fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus.

 

Fibers of these fasciculi synapse on the second-order neurons of the ipsilateral nuclei gracilis and cuneatus in the medulla oblongata, respectively.

 

Axons of these second-order neurons then cross over as the internal arcuate fibers to form the medial lemniscus in the contralateral medulla.

 

These second-order axons ascend through the brainstem to reach the third-order neuronal cell bodies in the ventral posterior lateral nucleus of the thalamus. Axons from the third-order neurons then project through the posterior limb of the internal capsule to reach the primary somatosensory cortex.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spinothalamic tract: The spinothalamic tract is an important ascending pathway that primarily carries pain, temperature, and crude touch sensations. The pathway originates from the spinal cord and projects directly to the thalamus without becoming the medial lemniscus. However, after relaying in the thalamus, fibers from the spinothalamic tract and the medial lemniscus converge to project to similar regions of the cerebral cortex.

 

Option B. Spinocerebellar tract: The spinocerebellar tracts (anterior and posterior) are pathways that convey proprioceptive information (concerning the position and movement of body parts) from the body to the cerebellum. They do not form the medial lemniscus.

 

Option C. Spinotectal tract: The spinotectal tract is an ascending pathway that carries sensory information related to reflex movements of the eyes and head in response to visual and tactile stimuli. It connects the spinal cord to the tectum of the midbrain (specifically, the superior colliculus). It does not become the medial lemniscus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fasciculus gracilis (and its counterpart, the fasciculus cuneatus) are ascending tracts in the spinal cord that carry fine touch, vibration, and proprioceptive sensations from the body to the brain.

 

These fibers travel upwards in the spinal cord and synapse in the nucleus gracilis (and nucleus cuneatus for the fasciculus cuneatus) located in the medulla oblongata. After synapsing, second-order neurons cross the midline and form the medial lemniscus, which then ascends to the thalamus.

 

Thus, the medial lemniscus is indeed a continuation of the fibers originally present in the fasciculus gracilis (and fasciculus cuneatus).

choices.text: Nothing, since CT was normal
Start on aspirin + clopidogrel
Advice BP control

questions.text: A patient presents with left-sided facial paralysis and weakness for the past 1 hour. Her blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg and CT shows dense MCA sign. What would be your next step? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intravenous thrombolysis

 

The patient's presentation of acute left-sided facial paralysis and weakness, alongside the finding of a dense MCA (Middle Cerebral Artery) sign on a CT scan, indicates an acute ischemic stroke. The dense MCA sign is a radiologic indicator of a thrombus or embolus in the MCA, which is one of the most common sites for cerebral infarctions.

 

Given that the symptoms began only 1 hour ago and the CT has confirmed the location of the occlusion without showing any signs of hemorrhage or extensive infarction (which would contraindicate thrombolysis), intravenous thrombolysis is the most appropriate intervention. This treatment is aimed at dissolving the clot and restoring blood flow to the affected area of the brain.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nothing, since CT was normal: Incorrect because the CT was not normal; it showed a dense MCA sign, indicating an acute stroke.

 

Option B. Start on aspirin + clopidogrel: This would generally be considered in secondary prevention after the acute management phase of ischemic stroke, or if the patient was not a candidate for thrombolysis.

 

Option D. Advice BP control: While controlling blood pressure is important, it is not the immediate next step in the management of a patient showing signs of acute ischemic stroke with a window for thrombolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of acute ischemic stroke with clear indications, intravenous thrombolysis should be administered as soon as possible within the therapeutic window to improve outcomes. Immediate evaluation and management are critical to maximize recovery and minimize long-term disability.

questions.text: Tigroid white matter on MRI imaging is seen in which of the following conditions? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease

 

Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease (PMD) is a rare, genetic, demyelinating disorder of the central nervous system characterized by a distinctive "tigroid" pattern on MRI. This pattern arises from the preservation of perivascular myelin in the brain's white matter, interspersed with areas of demyelination, creating a striped or tigroid appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pantothenate kinase deficiency: This condition is also known as PKAN (Pantothenate Kinase-Associated Neurodegeneration). It typically shows a characteristic MRI feature known as the "eye of the tiger" sign, which involves a specific pattern of iron deposition in the basal ganglia. The "eye of the tiger" sign appears due to a combination of hyperintense signal surrounded by a region of hypointensity on T2-weighted MRI images, reflecting iron accumulation and gliosis. This is distinct from the tigroid pattern seen in demyelinating diseases.

 

Option B. Neuroferritinopathy: Neuroferritinopathy is another disorder of iron metabolism that affects the brain, leading to iron accumulation, particularly in the basal ganglia. MRI findings in neuroferritinopathy typically do not include the tigroid pattern but may show abnormalities such as signal changes in the basal ganglia related to iron deposition. The imaging features here are more associated with iron accumulation rather than the patchy demyelination that produces the tigroid appearance.

 

Option D. Aceruloplasminemia: Aceruloplasminemia is a rare hereditary disorder characterized by iron accumulation in various tissues, including the brain. Similar to neuroferritinopathy, the primary MRI findings in aceruloplasminemia are related to iron deposition, particularly in the cerebellum and basal ganglia, and do not typically involve the tigroid pattern. Instead, the imaging might show evidence of iron accumulation without the specific changes associated with demyelination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease is a prototypical condition that displays a tigroid pattern on MRI. This appearance is due to the patchy preservation and destruction of myelin in the white matter, creating alternating areas of normal myelin and demyelination. This results in the characteristic striped or tigroid appearance on imaging studies, reflective of the disease’s impact on myelination.

questions.text: Banding technique used for dicentric chromosomes:(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C

 

Explanation:

 

Dicentric chromosome is an abnormal chromosome with two centromeres.

 

 

C banding: stains heterochromatin which are regions of the chromosomes at or near centromere. So, C banding will be most useful for dicentric chromosomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. G-banding: G-banding is the most common banding technique and uses Giemsa stain to stain AT-rich regions. It was developed as an alternative to Q-banding due to the cumbersome nature of Q-banding.

 

Option B. NOR-banding: NOR-banding (Nucleolar Organizer Region) is used to stain regions associated with nucleolus formation and is not specifically useful for dicentric chromosomes.

 

Option D. R-banding: R-banding provides a reverse pattern to G-banding, staining GC-rich regions instead of AT-rich regions. It is not specifically useful for identifying dicentric chromosomes.

 

Note –  Q banding: uses quinacrine dye (first used dye) and stains repetitive AT rich regions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

C-banding is the preferred technique for identifying dicentric chromosomes as it specifically stains heterochromatin regions at or near the centromere.

 

Reference: Robbins 10th Ed. / page- 262-263, 293

questions.text: A patient has been brought with severe bleeding to your ER. His blood group is unknown. Fresh frozen plasma from which of the following blood groups can be given? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) AB

 

FFP from AB blood group can be given to this patient since the universal plasma donor is AB. AB plasma does not contain antibodies against antigens on RBCs of AB blood group.

 

Here, the question is about fresh frozen plasma transfusion and not about the packed red cells.

 

Had the question been about packed RBCs then in case of emergency packed cell blood transfusion with unknown blood group, O Rh-negative blood (universal donor) is transfused. It is preferred because it lacks the A and B and Rh antigens. Hence, it cannot be hemolyzed by anti-A, anti-B or anti-D antibodies in the recipient's blood.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: By which cell of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma arises? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Naive B cells

 

The cell of origin of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL)/ Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (SLL) is either naïve B cells or post-germinal centre memory B cell.

 

 

 

FCL = Follicular Cell Lymphoma; MALT = Marginal Zone Lymphoma of Mucosa-Associated Lymphoid Tissue; MCL = Mantle Cell Lymphoma; SLL/CLL = Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma/Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mature B cells: While mature B cells can give rise to certain types of lymphomas, CLL/SLL specifically arises from naive B cells or post-germinal center memory B cells.

 

Option B. Mature T cells: Mature T cells are associated with different types of lymphomas, such as T-cell lymphomas, not CLL/SLL.

 

Option C. Progenitor T cells: Progenitor T cells are involved in the development of T-cell leukemias and lymphomas, such as T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia, not CLL/SLL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma arises from naive B cells or post-germinal center memory B cells, distinguishing it from other B-cell and T-cell malignancies.

questions.text: Reinke crystals are seen in which of the following gonadal tumours: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Leydig cell tumor

 

  • Reinke crystals are a specific and distinguishing feature of Leydig cell tumors. These crystals are eosinophilic, rod-shaped, crystalline inclusions found in the cytoplasm of Leydig cells. Leydig cell tumors are non-germ cell, sex cord-stromal tumors of the testicles that are typically benign.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seminoma: Does not feature Reinke crystals; characterized by uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and central nuclei, often associated with lymphocytic infiltration.

 

Option B. Yolk sac Tumor: Lacks Reinke crystals; known for Schiller-Duval bodies and a pattern resembling endodermal sinus structures.

 

Option D. Sertoli cell Tumor: Also does not contain Reinke crystals; these tumors may show tubular or trabecular growth patterns and are often clinically silent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reinke crystals are pathognomonic of Leydig cell tumors of the testis and are useful in differentiating these from other testicular neoplasms.

choices.text: Change the fluid to normal saline
Continue the surgery with careful monitoring of fluid status
Give furosemide to the patient and continue surgery

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady with submucosal fibroid was undergoing myomectomy. The surgeon was using 1.5% glycine as irrigating fluid for the cavity. During the surgery, the nurse informs that there is a 500ml deficit of the irrigating fluid. What is the next step to be done? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Continue the surgery with careful monitoring of fluid status

 

During hysteroscopy, systemic absorption of uterine distension fluid occurs through open sinuses or vessels. Increased fluid absorption is seen with higher intrauterine pressure, longer procedure duration, deep myometrial penetration, and a large uterus.

 

Excessive absorption of hypotonic electrolyte-free fluids, such as 1.5% glycine, can cause hypo-osmolality, hyponatremia, cerebral edema, hypotonic encephalopathy, permanent neurologic injury, heart failure, pulmonary edema, and death. However, in this case, the fluid deficit is 500 mL, which is within the allowable limits for a healthy patient.

 

Fluid Management Guidelines:

 

  • Hypotonic solutions (e.g., 1.5% glycine): The maximum allowed fluid deficit is 1000 mL for healthy patients and 750 mL for elderly patients or those with medical comorbidities.
  • Normal saline: The maximum allowed fluid deficit is 2500 mL for healthy patients and 750 mL for those with cardiovascular disease.

 

Fluid absorption can be reduced by:

 

  • Pre-operative treatment with GnRH agonists.
  • Intraoperative injection of dilute vasopressin (0.05 U/mL).
  • Using the lowest intrauterine pressure that provides adequate visualization, ensuring it is below the mean arterial pressure.

 

Management of fluid overload:

 

  • Hypotonic fluid overload: Obtain serum electrolytes and evaluate the patient for volume overload. Asymptomatic hyponatremia can be treated with fluid restriction and careful monitoring of urine output. Symptomatic hyponatremia requires infusion of 3% sodium chloride and management in intensive care.
  • Normal saline overload: Managed by fluid restriction; IV furosemide (20-40 mg) is indicated if there is clinical or radiological evidence of pulmonary edema.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Stop the surgery: This is not necessary at a fluid deficit of 500 mL, as it is within the safe limit for a healthy patient.

 

Option B. Change the fluid to normal saline: While normal saline can be used, it is not required to change the fluid type mid-procedure unless there are signs of significant complications or excessive fluid absorption.

 

Option D. Give furosemide to the patient and continue surgery: Furosemide is indicated if there is evidence of fluid overload or pulmonary edema, which is not the case here with a 500 mL deficit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of a 500 mL fluid deficit during hysteroscopy with 1.5% glycine as the irrigating fluid, it is appropriate to continue the surgery with car

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg903

questions.text: Early onset pre-eclampsia is defined as: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Before 34 weeks

 

Early onset pre-eclampsia is defined as pre-eclampsia that develops before 34 weeks of gestation. 

 

Early onset pre-eclampsia:

 

  • Indicates potentially higher severity
  • Is associated with conditions like antiphospholipid antibody syndrome
  • Can be prevented by administering low-dose aspirin

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Early onset pre-eclampsia is defined as pre-eclampsia occurring before 34 weeks of gestation, while late-onset pre-eclampsia occurs after 34 weeks.

questions.text: Shortest anterior posterior diameter of the pelvic inlet: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Obstetric conjugate

 

The obstetric conjugate is the shortest anterior-posterior diameter of the pelvic inlet through which the baby passes during delivery. It extends from the sacral promontory to a point on the posterior surface of the pubic symphysis. This is the clinically significant diameter as it represents the actual space available for fetal descent.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Anatomical conjugate (also called true conjugate): This extends from the sacral promontory to the upper border of pubic symphysis. While it is a pelvic measurement, it has no clinical significance.

 

Option B. Diagonal conjugate: This is measured during pelvic examination from the sacral promontory to the lower border of pubic symphysis. When 1.5 cm is subtracted from the diagonal conjugate, we get the obstetric conjugate.

 

 Option D. True conjugate: This is the same as the anatomical conjugate, extending from the sacral promontory to the upper border of pubic symphysis. It has no clinical significance.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The obstetric conjugate is the shortest and most clinically significant anterior-posterior diameter of the pelvic inlet, measuring from the sacral promontory to the posterior surface of the pubic symphysis. The diagonal conjugate can be measured clinically, and subtracting 1.5 cm from it gives the obstetric conjugate.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a stimulus for catecholamine synthesis? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyperglycemia

 

Hyperglycemia is not a stimulus for catecholamine synthesis. Physiologically, hyperglycemia can suppress catecholamine synthesis. While hyperglycemic emergencies may indirectly lead to increased catecholamines due to shock and osmotic diuresis, hyperglycemia itself does not directly stimulate catecholamine production. Hypoglycemia (not hyperglycemia) is a potent stimulus for catecholamine release, leading to autonomic symptoms like tremors, palpitations, anxiety, and sweating.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Smoking: Incorrect. Smoking is a known stimulus for catecholamine synthesis. Nicotine triggers the release of catecholamines from the adrenal medulla and sympathetic nerve endings.

 

Option B. Standing posture: Incorrect. Orthostatic changes require a catecholamine surge to prevent orthostatic hypotension when a person stands up. This is a normal physiological response.

 

Option D. Exercise: Incorrect. Exercise is one of the major physiological stimuli for catecholamine synthesis. Physical activity requires increased sympathetic activation and catecholamine production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypoglycemia (not hyperglycemia) is a potent stimulus for catecholamine release, leading to autonomic symptoms like tremors, palpitations, anxiety, and sweating. Hyperglycemia does not stimulate catecholamine synthesis.

choices.text: Urine specimen is used
Sanger sequencing is used
Study of fluid in tumor microenvironment
DNA is collected in micro vessels

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding liquid-based cytology? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urine specimen is used

 

Liquid-based cytology can also be done using a urine specimen. It is commonly used in cervical cancer screening in place of a pap smear.

 

Liquid-based cytology is a method of preparing samples for examination in cytopathology. The sample is collected, normally by a small brush, in the same way as for a conventional smear test, but rather than the smear being transferred directly to a microscope slide, the sample is deposited into a small bottle of preservative liquid. At the laboratory, the liquid is treated to remove other elements such as mucus before a layer of cells is placed on a slide.

 

Liquid-based cytology uses:

 

  • Used in place of PAP smear for cervical screening (most common use)
  • Thyroid cyst fluid examination.
  • Oral lesions
  • Body fluids sampling (e.g., urine, pleural effusions), brushing samples (e.g. gastrointestinal tract, lung), and fine needle aspiration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sanger sequencing is used: Sanger sequencing is a method of DNA sequencing and is not related to liquid-based cytology.

 

Option C. Study of fluid in tumor microenvironment: Liquid-based cytology is not specifically focused on the study of tumor microenvironment fluids; rather, it is a method for preparing and analyzing cellular samples.

 

Option D. DNA is collected in micro vessels: This is not a description of liquid-based cytology but may relate to other molecular biology techniques.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Liquid-based cytology can use urine specimens, among others, to prepare samples for cytological examination, offering advantages over traditional smear techniques in terms of sample preservation and clarity.

questions.text: Features of MEN2B are all of the following except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PTH carcinoma

 

MEN2B includes "Medullary thyroid cancer, Pheochromocytoma, Other extra features → Marfanoid habitus, Mucosal neuromas." Parathyroid involvement (PTH carcinoma) is not a component of MEN2B syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with schizophrenia was started on risperidone. After taking the medication last night, the patient rushes to OPD today with complaints of upwards rolling of his eyes. What is the management of the condition? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Promethazine

 

The patient is experiencing oculogyric crisis, which is an acute dystonic reaction caused by antipsychotic medications. This is an extrapyramidal side effect that involves sustained, involuntary upward deviation of the eyes.

 

This is an antihistamine with anticholinergic properties. It's commonly used as the first-line treatment for acute dystonic reactions, including oculogyric crisis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lorazepam: Useful for generalized dystonia or akathisia but not the first line for acute oculogyric crisis.

 

Option C. Olanzapine: Another antipsychotic, it wouldn't directly treat the acute dystonic reaction.

 

Option D. Stop antipsychotic: While it might be necessary to review and adjust the antipsychotic regimen if a patient is having side effects, simply stopping the antipsychotic won't provide immediate relief from an acute dystonic reaction.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acute dystonia, an extrapyramidal side effect, is characterized by spasm of muscles in any part of the body, e.g., oculogyric crisis, torticollis. It is seen in about 10% of patients on antipsychotics. Risk factors include young males, those who are antipsychotic naive and high potency antipsychotics. It usually occurs within hours of starting antipsychotic medication. They can be distressing but are reversible. Anticholinergic agents like promethazine (IM or IV) are first-line treatments for these reactions.

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 110-111

questions.text: What is the action of the superior oblique muscle? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intorsion, abduction, depression

 

  • The superior oblique muscle is responsible for three actions: intorsion, depression, and abduction.
  • Each eye has six extraocular muscles: four recti muscles and two oblique muscles.
  • The recti muscles are the superior, inferior, medial, and lateral rectus.
  • The superior oblique muscle originates from the apex of the orbit, turns around the trochlea, and inserts into the sclera behind the equator.
  • The tendon's oblique direction gives it a rotator effect, resulting in intorsion, as well as depression and abduction.
  • These muscles control both unilateral and binocular movements of the eye.
  • Unilateral eye movements are called Ductions.
  • Bilateral eye movements are called Versions.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The illustration below shows alternative splicing of a gene which has intron segments 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5. It yields two products A and B, by the action of different promoters. You are provided with the promoters W, X, Y, and Z, each of which binds to a different segment as shown below and acts in the marked direction. Which of the following promoters will you use to get product A? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. W Y

 

Explanation:

 

A promoter is a region of DNA upstream of a gene where relevant proteins bind to initiate

transcription of that gene. In the case of this question, product A is formed by including specific

segments and excluding others through the process of alternative splicing.

 

  • Sequence A consists of segments 1, 3, 4, and 5.
    • Promoter W Required for segment 1.
    • Promoter Y Required for segments 3, 4, and 5.
    • Segment 2 is excluded during alternative splicing.

 

Thus, the combination of Promoters W and Y will result in the production of sequence A by including

the correct segments and excluding segment 2.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a (W, X, Y): This combination Required Promoter X, for segment 2, but it

    is unnecessary since W and Y alone are sufficient to yield product A.

  • Option b (W, Z): Promoter Z does not include segments 3, making this option incorrect for generating product A.
  • Option c (WX): Promoters W and X are insufficient because they do not include segments 3, 4, and 5, which are essential for product A.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A promoter is a region of DNA upstream of a gene where relevant proteins bind to initiate

transcription of that gene.

 

Using promoters W, Y will yield product A by including segments 1, 3, 4, and 5 and removing segment 2 through alternative splicing.

questions.text: Reason of Hepatomegaly in Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Accumulation of glycogen

 

The reason for hepatomegaly (enlarged liver) in this disease is the accumulation of glycogen. Glucose-6-phosphatase is an enzyme involved in gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis. When there is a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase, the normal breakdown of glycogen into glucose is impaired, leading to the accumulation of glycogen within the liver.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Accumulation of Glucose-6-phosphate: While glucose-6-phosphate is an intermediate in glycogenolysis, its accumulation is not the primary cause of hepatomegaly in glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency. Increased Glu-6-P however causes other C/f such as Hyperuricemia, hypertriglyceridemia and Lactic acidosis.

 

Option C. Accumulation of Glucose-1-phosphate: Glucose-1-phosphate is an intermediate in glycogenolysis. It does not accumulate in Von Gierke’s disease.

 

Option D. Accumulation of glycogenin: Glycogenin is a protein that plays a role in initiating glycogen synthesis, not breakdown. Accumulation of glycogenin is not a typical feature of glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is known as Von Gierke’s disease or Type I GSD.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked with a yellow question mark ? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inner nuclear layer

 

The marked structure in the slide is the inner nuclear layer of the retina

 

  • Present between the outer plexiform layer and the inner plexiform layer.
  • Contains the cell bodies of bipolar cells, horizontal cells, and amacrine cells.
  • Dark stain.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the most common cause for hospital admission after day care surgery? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Postoperative nausea and vomiting

 

Explanation:

 

The most common cause for hospital admission or delayed discharge from the hospital post day care surgery is Postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV). PONV is a frequent complication following surgery and anesthesia, significantly impacting patient comfort and recovery, and often leading to extended hospital stays or readmissions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory distress: While it is a serious concern, it is not as commonly the cause for hospital admission after day care surgery as PONV.

 

Option B. Post-surgical pain: Although post-surgical pain is a common issue, it is generally managed effectively with analgesics and is less frequently the cause for hospital admission compared to PONV.

 

Option D. Bleeding: Postoperative bleeding can be a complication but is less common as a cause for hospital admission after day care surgery compared to PONV.

 

Risk factors for PONV:

 

 

Educational Objective :

 

Postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) is the most common cause for hospital admission or delayed discharge after day care surgery.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 2603

questions.text:
Arrange the following prenatal scans in the correct chronological order during pregnancy:

 

  1. Nuchal Translucency Scan
  2. Triple Marker Test
  3. Anomaly Scan
  4. Growth Scan
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

The correct sequence of prenatal scans during pregnancy is as follows:

 

  • Nuchal Translucency (NT) Scan: This ultrasound is performed between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation. It measures the thickness of the translucent area at the back of the fetal neck. An increased NT measurement can indicate a higher risk of chromosomal abnormalities, such as Down syndrome, and certain structural anomalies, including heart defects. 
  • Triple Marker Test: Conducted during the second trimester, typically between 15 and 20 weeks of gestation, this blood test measures levels of three substances: alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), and unconjugated estriol. Abnormal levels can indicate an increased risk of chromosomal abnormalities, such as Down syndrome, and neural tube defects. 
  • Anomaly Scan: Also known as the fetal anomaly scan or targeted imaging for fetal anomalies (TIFFA), this detailed ultrasound is usually performed between 18 and 23 weeks of gestation. It assesses the fetal anatomy to detect any structural abnormalities.
  • Growth Scan: Typically performed between 28 and 32 weeks of gestation, this ultrasound evaluates fetal growth, amniotic fluid volume, and placental position to ensure the fetus is developing appropriately.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct chronological order of prenatal scans during pregnancy is:

 

  1. Nuchal Translucency Scan (11–14 weeks)
  2. Triple Marker Test (15–20 weeks)
  3. Anomaly Scan (18–23 weeks)
  4. Growth Scan (28–32 weeks)

questions.text: A patient with diabetic macular edema developed glaucoma. Which of the following drugs would you consider giving last?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Prostaglandin analogues

 

Prostaglandin analogues are effective drugs for reducing intraocular pressure in glaucoma patients by increasing the outflow of aqueous humor through the uveoscleral pathway. However, they can also cause side effects that might exacerbate conditions like macular edema, which is a consideration in this patient who has diabetic macular edema.

 

Side Effects of Prostaglandin Analogues:

 

  • Cystoid Macular Edema: This is a known side effect of prostaglandin analogues and can worsen the existing macular edema in a diabetic patient.
  • Iris Hyperpigmentation: This is generally a cosmetic issue but can be a concern for some patients.
  • Hypertrichosis: This involves increased growth of eyelashes, which is usually considered a benign side effect.

 

Given the risk of exacerbating macular edema, prostaglandin analogues should be considered last in the treatment plan for this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta Blockers:

 

  • Mechanism: Beta blockers like timolol reduce intraocular pressure by decreasing the production of aqueous humor.
  • Side Effects: They are generally well-tolerated in glaucoma treatment and do not exacerbate macular edema. Common side effects include bradycardia and bronchospasm, especially in patients with pre-existing respiratory conditions.

 

Option B. Alpha agonist:

 

  • Mechanism: Alpha agonists such as brimonidine reduce aqueous humor production and increase uveoscleral outflow.
  • Side Effects: These drugs can cause dry mouth, fatigue, and ocular allergies, but they do not significantly affect macular edema.

 

Option C. Pilocarpine:

 

  • Mechanism: Pilocarpine is a miotic agent that increases aqueous humor outflow through the trabecular meshwork.
  • Side Effects: It can cause miosis, accommodative spasm, and brow ache. Pilocarpine does not exacerbate macular edema but is less commonly used due to its side effect profile and the need for frequent dosing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystoid Macular edema is one of the side effects of Prostaglandin analogues. The other side effects are Iris hyperpigmentation and hypertrichosis of the eye lashes.

questions.text:
Organize the subsequent afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle, proceeding from the medial to the lateral direction. (INICET MAY 2023)

 

1. General somatic

2. General visceral

3. Special somatic

4. Special visceral
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2, 4, 1, 3

 

The question is regarding afferent columns hence we will only look at the afferent columns to arrange these options and not the whole arrangement of all the columns in the diagram.

 

The afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle can be categorized from medial to lateral into four types: general visceral, special visceral, general somatic, and special somatic.

 

 

 

The subsequent afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle can be organized from medial to lateral as follows:

 

2. General visceral: The general visceral column carries sensory information from the internal organs, such as the visceral sensations of hunger, fullness, and discomfort.

 

4. Special visceral: This column includes sensory input related to the special senses of taste and hearing. The special visceral sensory column carries information from the taste buds and the cochlea (auditory part of the ear).

 

1. General somatic: The general somatic column carries sensory information related to touch, temperature, pain, and pressure from the body's skin and musculoskeletal system.

 

3. Special somatic: This column contains sensory input related to the special senses of vision, equilibrium, and proprioception (awareness of body position). It includes input from the eyes, ears (for balance), and proprioceptors in muscles and joints.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the floor of the fourth ventricle, the arrangement of the afferent sensory columns from medial to lateral is - 2. General visceral, 4. Special visceral, 1. General somatic & 3. Special somatic

choices.text: Medroxy progesterone acetate

questions.text: Which among the following is an ideal treatment for a 55-year-old female with simple hyperplasia of the endometrium with atypia? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Simple hysterectomy

 

For postmenopausal women with atypical hyperplasia of the endometrium, the recommended treatment is a total hysterectomy. This approach is taken due to the increased risk of progression to endometrial carcinoma, especially given the presence of atypia and the patient's postmenopausal status.

 

  • Simple Hysterectomy: This involves the surgical removal of the uterus and is considered the ideal treatment for postmenopausal women with endometrial hyperplasia with atypia to prevent the progression to cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medroxyprogesterone acetate: This is a progestogen treatment used primarily for managing endometrial hyperplasia without atypia, especially in women who desire to preserve fertility. It is not the ideal treatment for atypical hyperplasia in a postmenopausal woman.

 

Option C. Levonorgestrel: The Levonorgestrel intrauterine system (LNG-IUS) is used for managing endometrial hyperplasia without atypia and as a conservative treatment for women wishing to preserve fertility. However, it is not the treatment of choice for atypical hyperplasia in a postmenopausal woman.

 

Option D. Radiotherapy: This is not a standard treatment for endometrial hyperplasia with atypia. It is typically reserved for more advanced or inoperable endometrial cancers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For postmenopausal women with endometrial hyperplasia with atypia, the ideal treatment is a total hysterectomy to prevent progression to endometrial carcinoma.

 

Ref: Page no 330, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition
